summary: This is an email chain from November 30, 2018, between federal prosecutors and FBI agents in the Southern District of New York discussing the Jeff Epstein matter. It shows early coordination following a Miami Herald article, with prosecutors noting the Florida non-prosecution agreement has no legal effect on them and characterizing the case as trafficking.

persons.name: Kim
persons.context: A federal prosecutor in the Southern District of New York who is part of the email chain discussing the Epstein matter and scheduling a call.

persons.name: A. (NY) (FBI)
persons.context: An FBI agent in New York who suggests a call to discuss gathered information on the Jeff Epstein matter and coordinate next steps.

connections.description: They are communicating and coordinating a call to discuss the Jeff Epstein investigation, indicating a prosecutorial-law enforcement working relationship.

events.title: Coordination call on Epstein matter
events.description: FBI agents and federal prosecutors in the Southern District of New York schedule a call to discuss information gathered on Jeff Epstein and determine the way forward.

events.title: Miami Herald article published
events.description: A Miami Herald article about Jeff Epstein is referenced, prompting federal prosecutors to reach out to the FBI for insight.

events.title: Prior conversation referenced
events.description: A prosecutor references a brief conversation from July 2001 before coming to the current role, though the exact context is unclear.

keyFacts: Federal prosecutors in the Southern District of New York determined that the Florida non-prosecution agreement (NPA) with Epstein had no legal effect on their potential prosecution.
A prosecutor in the email chain explicitly states 'It's trafficking,' indicating their early legal characterization of the Epstein case.
The email chain was triggered by a Miami Herald article published on November 29, 2018, which detailed Epstein's past cooperation in a financial fraud case and non-prosecution.
The correspondence shows early investigative coordination between the U.S. Attorney's Office and the FBI in New York regarding Epstein in late 2018.
